div.p:
Dr Birdwood
The curator of the Botanical gardenGarden
and Museum here told me yester-
day that he would recommend
you to the Governor as a fit
person to occupy his place - He
was at college with you but did
not know you otherwise than by
sight - As it is likely from what
I said to the Governor that you
may get an offer I shall try to
give you as clear an idea of the
affair as possible - The salary is
300 Rupees a month say £500 or
£600 a year with a good house
which as rents have risen
enormously is as much more
He is going to ask an advance of
pay & believes it will be £RRupees700 a
month or £840. This is not so
much as it looks like owing to the
high price of living now in Bom-
bay - A horse & phaeton with horse
boy servants would cost you
in your free house 300 RRupees or £300
div.ab:
a sad end was that of poor Rae - Mr Brown of
the same company now says that they are
div.p:
month, so with your RRupees 500 to 700
you would have £20 & £40 over
say £240 or £480 to same yearly
the cost of horse & phaeton would
be £150 - In house is in the Botanic
Garden - and that is new - The
Museum is only building - and
is rather a fine building at the
entrance to the Garden - you would
direct the planting out and select
plants - seeds and have men under
you to do the work - The situation
is flat, and during the monsoon
patches of water lie adjacent - Dr
Birdwood has been the chief hand
in getting up the gardensgarden's looks on
them with great affection, and
hence his anxiety to get a fit occupant
while he retires I believe for a time
on account of want of wealth &
having been ten years out in
Bombay - He suffers from fever
and his stomach cannot bear
quinine or arsenic - He is rather
desponding as to his state of health
The GovernorsGovernor's band plays in the
gardens & people flock to hear it -
as you are a lady killer you might
be successful in the matrimonial
line there - Fruit & vegetables you
would have free - The medical
professor does not stand high
div.ab: disassociated from the sultan now - the will hire
div.p:
and you would have a fair share
in home probably a large one - of the
practice - Dr Birdwood devotes
his time more to literary pursuits
than practice, hence & guess his duties
do not occupy a large portion of
his time - He is GovGovernor Secretary to the
Bombay Asiatic societySociety & something
else which bring honour & bother
only - My impression is that if
nothing better has turned up yet
and the offer comes you might
accept it as a step in the right
direction - If employed the Governor
would provide for you elsewhere
in the event of Birdwood resuming
his duties - He gave his private
physician Dr Steadman a good
appointment as head of the Sir
Jamsetyee JhejeebhoyJamsetjee Jeejebhoy hospital -
there are many Scotchmen here - and
they are clannish but all making
money & eager to go home - The
climate is not good but with care
one may enjoy good health - whether
you ought to take this when offered
as a stepping stone to something
else or decline it as likely to shelve
you into Indian ways I cantcan't say
It is an important step in life and
with more risk than at home - I
would run the risk of a higher

div.p:
stake than usually offers a shove
but you must decide & I trust
that God will give wisdom
to act for the best -

It is rather premature in me
to write so much about what
His Excellency may or may not
do - I think it likely He will be
disposed to make you an offer
He is a very good man - is accused
of being too soft - but it is in man-
-ner only - when I hear more
I shall let you have it This
goes by a new company started
by American'sAmericans "Stearns Hobart &c"
who send cotton by the overland
route & charge only £60 ^ passage money from this
to Liverpool - I am living with
one of them Mr Stearns a very
good fellow - I dontdon't know my
starting day & hence I write now
in case of being called off - all
my men are ready - I am not
to wait for a man of war but go
in one of Sherow OsbornesOsborne's fleet
called Mule a present of the Sultan
of Zanzibar - Seward is acting
there - no appointment has been
made Affectionably yours
David Livingstone
